name: MODEL 500
description:
This board was used as a motherboard for the Challenger II.
Three Model 500 versions were sold:
500: The board.
500-1: Fully enclosed board with power supply, reset switch and two standard terminal connectors.
500-8: A 500 board in an eight slot Challenger case with power supply.
OHIO Scientific presented later an enhanced version called SuperKit. It was a 3 board-set with a Model 500 board without the serial interface, a video board, a 8 slot backplane board and a modified version of the BASIC ROM allowing a direct use of the video board. A TV set could be used with an optional RF aerial modulator

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> THE MODEL 500 SUPERKIT</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Superkit is a kit with several boards : an expansion board with 8 slots, the Model 500 board and a card called Model 440 Video I/O board. This card provides CRT functions and a keyboard connector.</blockquote>

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD #1 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Better features, cheaper price, the PC price war  has just started.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LISA ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>He is rich (enough to buy a LISA !), he is relaxed... He is the typical advertising executive of the 80's.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT JUNE 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said: <br><br><font color="#666666"> With NEC's PC-8800 personal computer, you don't have to ask yourself which comes first, the hardware or the software.<br> It's designed to be uncompromising in both areas. So you come first. In the office or at home.<br> The hardware gives you your choice of 8-bit or 16-bit processors, 5 1/4" or 8" disk drives and standard green or high resolution color monitor.<br> The software includes advanced, user friendly programs for all types of banking, accounting and business management. Plus free WordStar word processing, and MailMerge, Multiplan spread sheet, BASIC (two versions), and CP/M... </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMO PIC #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>This promotional picture was used to emphasize the programming assets of the TO-7/70 : Microsoft Basic v5, Microsoft assembler and SOLI Logo. They want to make us believe that architects used TO-7/70 !  <br><br> As usual there are no cables shown... The arm looks weird, lifeless... did they cut it to take the picture more easily ?! or is the woman completely laid down on the table ?</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>>  GERMAN LEAFLET #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Preliminary/New product leaflet. For exhibitions only<br><br><br> "The new Personal Computer from SHARP - particularly developed for personal use."<br><br> Note the optional Quick Disc drive.<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT MARCH 1982</strong></font><br><blockquote>From Personal Computing, March 1982 issue.<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT (1985?)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an advert for the Power 3000 released in the USA.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://hem.passagen.se/clab/adam/lambda/" target="_blank">Adam's Lambda 8300 page</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPARISON CHART #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juraj Mucko for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT. (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is nearly a stupid scan ! <br><br> The young boy says : ''In 1984, my father bought me a MO-5" <br> And on his desk is a 1998 calendar... <br><br> They meant that if you bought the MO-5 then (the advert is from 1984), you would be rich and clever 14 years later (in 1998). Ha ha ha !! <br><br> It's funny to see how they tried to represent an office and a town of 1998. I really love this one !  </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Carefully, one last time... I compared everything and I offered myself a BBC" <br><br> Lucky guy, he must be rich at more than 6300fr the BBC... At the end of the text we can read : <br><br> "The price : 6300fr maximum. Of course it's not given. More expensive than some (but I had already eliminated them)." !! <br><br> At least they are honest.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPUSTAR AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Compustar standard features in 1983:<br> - 350 KB / 750 KB / 1.5 MB workstation disk capacities<br> - 10 to 144 MB storage options<br><br> Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Compustar is built and backed by the company that's been in the microcomputer business as long as microcomputers have been in business. Would you trust your business to anything less?</font> </blockquote>
